text:

text: My personal favorite Zelda game. I remember people hating on Wind Waker either for its art style or for the tedious sailing, and every single one of them were declaring that Twilight Princess was going to be miles better... text: @wwTheTrueWarioww Lol yes having do restart a temple or just quests in general because you didn't make the time limit and then had to go back and technically lose all progress was BS imo even if it was intentional. Also how you actually save your game is one of the most retarded way to save I've ever heard of in my life. You'd think those flaws would actually break the game, but it really doesn't somehow. Guess there can never be a generally accepted Nintendo-made "bad" Zelda. :)

author: prince

text:
I prefer Wind Waker over Twilight Princess, 'cause WW surprised me in a positive way. When it was announced, I said: "WTF! A Zelda game can't look like that". But when I got it in 2003, I just loved its stunning, non-realistic, but beautiful graphics, and the sea feature. Too bad it was too short, though. 

On the other hand, I expected much more from TP. It's a great game, but it brought no innovation at all. It's just an Oot wannabe.

author: Zenith Everfloofs

text:
Zelda has always been catroonish. Just look up the old artwork, Zelda I , II , III , IV.
OoT was the game what did something new.

Windwaker took up the old style, and as we know, when you ''convert'' cartoon to 3D.. what does thou get? Yes; cel shaded graphics. 
The people who whine about it are either naiv and dumb, or just aren't true Zelda fans.
author: uigh

text:
@daviaker I like to think A Link to the Past "started" Zelda as we know it. I mean, ALttP basically gave us a lot of the famous Zelda themes (Zelda's lullaby, Ganon's theme, Hyrule Castle) and of course, started off the sort of plot progression we see in most Zelda games (3 things to collect, get Master Sword, collect some more stuff).

But I see what you mean. OoT was definitely very innovative and indeed, no other Zelda game has emulated its critical success.
author: JonnyJinx04

text: @JonnyJinx04 well technically not, but it got the highest rating on every game review sites compared to all its predecessors. Atleast for my generation that is born at the end of 80s or start of the 90s did not grow up with 8 bit, someone had super nintendo, but i think most had nintendo 64 and playstation, and the first game that introduced me to the zelda world was ocarina of time hehe. But i guess the older guys got more experience with the series than me.
author: David Heak

text: @jwild611 Believe me, even though the Cell-Shading can be pretty annoying for those of us that have grown attached to the old-style graphics, the game itself is extremely good, both gameplay and storywise. I would go for it. I got it at a rip-off price, but would gladly pay double that price knowing how good the thing is.

author: pjsmoulder

text:
not missing much?! this game was a rich cinematic tapestry, a beautiful spectrum of moods and emotions.

*SPOILER ALERT!*

remember the scene on top of the tower of the gods, where link rings the bell by swinging from it? the deep blue of the sky, the sound of the wind...

or the scene before when the triforce lights up on the water?

or when the pirates launch you from their catapult? hilarious.
author: pjsmoulder

text:
twilight princess had a complete lack of soul. it wasn't so much dark and gritty, as it was dark and empty. it felt cold compared to this.

windwaker felt like a legitimate evolution of oot and mm, twilight princess felt wrong.

text:

author: Laurelindo

text: The combat was certainly a lot more satisfying.
author: Talking Too Much About Games

text:
It's such a shame that this game was poorly received by the fans. They were just afraid to take any newness into the series.

It easily had the best soundtrack of any Zelda game.
author: Talking Too Much About Games

text:
It had a really unique and cool visual style, but don't look for high texture renders or a lot of realism. Gameplay was similar to other Zelda titles, if that's what you're looking for then it's quite fun. 

The vast amount of time you spend on the sea going from place to place gets monotonous but does convey a sense of space and isolation. 

If you need a Zelda fix and you finished the new one, maybe give it a spin. You're not missing much if you skip this one, tho.

text: I found this out a week or two ago: the legend at the beginning of the game that says Ganon was released and Link disappeared was talking about when you go back in time and take the sword out, which frees Ganon. He returned to the present, and Link was still in the past, which explains why the hero was "not present" when Ganon returned. So, the whole thing is Link's fault.
